material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The ratios between the hole and electron mobilities were calculated to be 3.2 and 13.6 for the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend and the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend films , respectively. The less balanced carrier transport in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film accounts for the lower FF. The polymers and polymer blend films were also analyzed by X-ray diffraction ( XRD ) studies. Figure 8 shows the XRD patterns of the polymers and the polymer : PC 70 BM blends. All film XRD results were similar and showed weak crystalline features with a broad peak around 23 ° . The crystalline features corresponding to π-stacking among the conjugated polymer backbones were also observed among TT - based polymers ; 25 however , the peaks were broader , and no crystalline peaks were observed at smaller angles around 4.4 ° . This less crystalline feature was possibly caused by the more twisted polymer backbones , as compared to PTB7 or PBDTTPD polymer backbones . In conclusion , we synthesized the low band gap POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers that consist of dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The DTPD acceptor moieties allow the POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers to have a low band gap ( ∼ 900 nm ) and optimal HOMO and LUMO levels alignment for PSCs , yielding the PCEs of 4.7 and 5.3% , respectively. In this study , we demonstrate , for the first time , that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - withdrawing building block for low band gap polymers , and it can be utilized to tailor the optical and electronic properties of conjugated polymers for photovoltaic devices and many other applications in plastic electronics.

Let's think step by step.

Here are the properties of the materials mentioned in the paragraph:

1. POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film
 * Hole mobility ratio: 3.2
 * Electron mobility ratio: 13.6
 * FF (Fill Factor): less balanced carrier transport, which is lower
2. PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film
 * Hole mobility ratio: 13.6
 * Electron mobility ratio: 3.2
 * FF (Fill Factor): less balanced carrier transport, which is lower
3. Polymers and polymer blend films
 * Crystalline feature: weak crystalline features with a broad peak around 23 °
 * Crystalline feature (π-stacking among the conjugated polymer backbones): observed among TT-based polymers
 * Crystalline peak: not observed at smaller angles around 4.4 °
 * Polymer backbones: more twisted, which possibly causes less crystalline features
4. POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers
 * Band gap: low (~900 nm)
 * HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) and LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) levels alignment: optimal for PSCs (Polymer Solar Cells)
 * PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency): 4.7% (POBDTPD) and 5.3% (PEBDTPD)

Here is the table of the valid relationships:

| Material Name | Material Property | Material Property (Abbr.) | Numerical Value | Condition |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film | Hole mobility ratio | HMR | 3.2 | - |
| POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film | Electron mobility ratio | EMR | 13.6 | - |
| PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film | Hole mobility ratio | HMR | 13.6 | - |
| PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film | Electron mobility ratio | EMR | 3.2 | - |
| Polymers and polymer blend films | Crystalline feature | CF | Weak crystalline features with a broad peak around 23 ° | - |
| TT-based polymers | Crystalline feature (π-stacking among the conjugated polymer backbones) | CF-π | Observed | - |
| Polymers and polymer blend films | Crystalline peak | CP | Not observed at smaller angles around 4.4 ° | - |
| POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers | Band gap | BG | Low (~900 nm) | - |
| POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers | HOMO and LUMO levels alignment | HOMO-LUMO | Optimal for PSCs | - |
| POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers | PCE | PCE | 4.7% (POBDTPD) and 5.3% (PEBDTPD) | - |
